title: Will conservatives retain their majority in the Majles after Iran's upcoming parliamentary elections?
preds: Dropping to match graph - my way of trying to mitigate the outcome in a neutral manner.

The elections occurred without any major demonstrations or security incidents, but an Interior Ministry official confirmed that a conflict among “candidates’ supporters” caused a shooting that wounded four people in Fars province. The runoff elections will determine 68 seats in the 290-member Parliament. The reformist-moderate bloc made major gains during the first round of elections in February to the detriment of the hardliners. No single faction won an outright majority, however, so the runoff elections will be crucial in determining Parliament’s final political makeup. Interior Ministry Spokesman Hossein Ali Amiri told reporters that election results will be announced on April 30, although he noted that this date could change.

A thought:  this question doesn't ask if the conservative COALITION will retain their majority, so it doesn't matter who the smaller parties (minority, independent, moderate conservatives) align themselves with; all that matters is if the conservatives get a majority.  With 290 seats total, a majority would be 146.  With only 103 seats so far,  the conservatives would have to get 43 of the 69 seats up for election today:  62% of the seats.  That seems unlikely to me.

I do not think that this question can be resolved fairly; I think it should be voided, or that Brier & Accuracy scores on it should not be calculated into averages.

How ideological orientations are determined among qualified candidates for election purposes will be the primary determinant to the outcome of this question.  Alliances, ideological labels, parliamentary voting patterns and pressure from IRGC and regime proponents will shape the direction that each parliamentary candidate asserts.    For example, moderate in Iran can be determined on a scale itself which include conservatives with a flavor of Principalist orientation.   How can such a candidate be classified if their ideological orientation is, for example, reformist but also pro-regime (ie., religious conservative assuming the central governance structure of theocracy)?  Are they reformist?  Are they moderates?  Are they principalist?

It seems to me that @Anneinak was right a few days ago, or at least on to something. We and the administrators are attempting to define what a "conservative" is in this election, without really understanding the cultural context, or what Iranians understand to be "conservatism," "moderation," and "liberalism." So we wind up reading our own assumptions into the question, then bean counting which party controls how many seats. Since "conservative" has no actual definition in this question, I think it should be voided. When it comes down to it, Zoroastrian monarchists are arguably the most conservative Iranians there are, but that's obviously not what the administrators mean. But it just goes to show that it's all a matter of definitions.

What's a poor forecaster to do?  I see reports that call out so-called moderate candidates for being conservatives in disguise.  I see reports about elected members of the Majlis who are expected to work with moderates somehow, but who are also expected to stand firm on conservative matters like women's issues, hard-core opposition to the West, and missile launches.  I'm not sure how one can tell who is and who isn't a conservative now.  There are no firm party affiliations that can be tallied.  This matter seems to have devolved into a bet on how GJO will adjudicate, rather than a bet on the original question.
Love the @Anneinak comment about the fluid Eastern circular system.  Who's a conservative?  Who's a reformist?  Who knows?  I'm so glad not to be the person who has to score this question.

I think that the root of the problem that everyone is having with this question--both in how it is stated and now is having to be argued and resolved-- is that we're trying to impose  rigid, western dualistic thinking in which "reformists" are fixed spots on the opposite end of the line from "conservatives", onto  a fluid, eastern circular system in which anyone can be at any point on the circle at any given moment.

Now I am gaming the GJP's likely definition of "conservative" rather than the actual result.    My supposition is that most people in academia are left-leaning, pro-Obama and want to see the Iran deal be successful.   Most leftists believe that the right outcome takes precedence over rule of law  (ends justify the means), and if the ends don't work out as promised, then at least "good intentions" were demonstrated.  It would be most encouraging, heartwarming and validating  for me and others to see the Iranian "conservatives" defeated as a result of the success of "moderate reformers" like Rouhani and Rafsanjani.   On the surface, the early election returns shows that what were previous defined as the "conservative slate" likely fell slightly short of a majority.   The "reform slate" did better than expected given the elimination of very many "reformers" from the lists, but these slots  on the "reformist slate" were craftily filled by other candidates more acceptable to the Mullahs (including some "conservatives" now running as "moderates").  My earlier forecasts in the 90 to 100% range did not take that brilliant campaign move into account (I did not do enough research and thought many candidates from the reformist slate were eliminated rather than replaced)

WHO’S WHO
•	with no clearly defined parties, it is a complicated task to discern where many prospective members of parliament stand in relation to government policies. 
•	The hard-liners/conservatives/”Principalists” have strict views on the enforcement of Islamic law and oppose closer relations with the outside world, including the nuclear deal.  They blame the economic stagnation on the policies of Rouhani and praise the work of the Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei in maintaining Iran’s position as a major regional power.  The conservative camp is increasingly defined by orthodoxy, and this is harming the moderates’ image among voters.
•	The moderates share some views with the Reformists, but do not like to be compared with the hard-liners, who are unpopular among the general public.  They  support the nuclear deal and the improved economic conditions to come following the lifting of sanctions.
•	Reformists will be led by a presidential candidate who stood aside in 2013 paving the way for Rouhani’s victory.
•	A middle ground list has emerged: the Voice of the Nation, led by a moderate conservative lawmaker known for his controversial positions including opposition to the ongoing house arrest of Mousavi and Karroubi.  
•	The exact numbers of candidates in the various camps is difficult to gauge, since they are spread out across hundreds of constituencies and many are relatively unknown politically.

The election process of the Majles is extremely restricted in what candidates may stand for election. In particular, the ability of Iran's Guardian Council to vet and reject candidates for election severely restricts the ability of moderates to even qualify for the ballot. registered candidates for the country’s parliamentary and Assembly of Experts elections next month has surged compared with previous polls, increasing by 100% and 60%, respectively. Although the Guardian Council is unlikely to approve all candidacies,...
...surge in the number of registered candidates can be traced to five main motivating factors....Moreover, since the norm of having political parties does not exist in Iran, some only put forth candidacies because they like the idea of going to the Ministry of Interior to register and getting the related media attention. In addition, considering the rate of unemployment and economic decline in Iran, certain educated but jobless individuals believe that becoming a member of parliament is an opportunity to gain access to better economic and political opportunities....Second is the Reformists’ strategy. Supporters of the Rouhani administration, including Reformists, have adopted the strategy of introducing a lot of candidates in the hopes that if their leading figures are disqualified, lesser-known Reformists will be given the chance to run for parliament and pursue the Reformist agenda. This strategy is useful for mobilizing people in order to change the political makeup of parliament and the Assembly of Experts, both of which are currently dominated by non-Reformists. Prominent Reformists can of course wield more influence and be more effective compared to second- or third-rate colleagues. However, the Reformists are not going to give up easily. They are hoping to at least increase the political cost for the conservatives if the Guardian Council engages in mass disqualifications of registered candidates....Third is the most important political turning point of Iran in the next 10 years. There is speculation that in the next decade, considering the age of Iran’s 76-year-old, ailing Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the country will have a new leader. Considering the authority enjoyed by the supreme leader within Iran’s political system, various groups are looking to secure their positions in the Assembly of Experts, which is tasked with selecting the next supreme leader. Rafsanjani’s proposal to establish a “leadership council” instead of a single supreme leader has been criticized by the conservatives but welcomed by the Reformists and alternative political thinkers. On the other hand, if Reformists and supporters of the Rouhani administration manage to win a majority of seats in parliament, sidelined Reformists can return to politics, and thus the atmosphere of moderation and reform long promised by Rouhani can finally be institutionalized....Fourth is women’s rights campaigns....Last but certainly not least is that the outcome of the latest presidential elections continues to impact Iranian politics. The 2013 presidential vote proved that by participating in elections and supporting a certain candidate, people can overcome some of their economic and political problems. Indeed, Iranians realized that by taking part in polls and electing Rouhani, they could help solve the nuclear crisis, which had been ongoing since 2003. It should not be overlooked that a majority of people believe that they can influence the politics of their country by casting their ballots.

January 4, 2016 4:22 pm - Iran’s hardliners seize on embassy attack anger to weaken Rouhani - Najmeh Bozorgmehr in Tehran
"They took selfies and posted cheery photos on social media as if they found setting ablaze the Saudi embassy in Tehran hilarious.
Earlier, dozens of protesters chanted “Mashallah, Mashallah” — “God willed it” — as they ransacked the embassy in protest against Riyadh’s execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, a prominent Shia cleric.
The Sunni Arab kingdom responded by severing ties with Tehran, with Bahrain and Sudan following Riyadh’s example. The United Arab Emirates also downgraded relations.
At first glance, it may appear that Islamic vigilantes had created a diplomatic crisis that fuelled tensions between the two regional superpowers.
But reform-minded analysts warned that Iran’s hardliners have exploited public outrage to undermine President Hassan Rouhani and his allies.
“Without doubt, the incident is related to the current tense political infighting,” said one analyst. “More bad news will come soon. There will be a further build-up of pressure on the reformists.”
Iran struck a landmark nuclear agreement with big powers last summer, which is expected to be implemented this month. The benefits of that accord — following the lifting of economic sanctions — should increase Mr Rouhani’s leverage in Iran’s sophisticated corridors of power.
Hardliners, who were shocked to lose to Mr Rouhani in the 2013 presidential election, hope to win back support in crucial polls next month after a series of setbacks, that included the nuclear deal.
“It is hard to believe that some people threw Molotov cocktails at the Saudi embassy and confiscated it for one or two hours without being supported by some [power] centres,” said Mohammad-Sadegh Javadi-Hesar, a reformist politician. “That’s why they easily take selfies and seem confident they will be rewarded for their radical stances.”
Iran’s hardliners are mostly based in the elite Revolutionary Guard, the judiciary, parliament, state-run television and the Guardian Council, a constitutional watchdog that vets candidates’ Islamic (and political) credentials. The council is expected to bar many reformist candidates from running for the polls by questioning their allegiance to the Islamic ideology.
After nearly a decade of isolation Iran has a deal with six world powers to wind back progress towards building a nuclear bomb in exchange for a reversal of international economic sanctions
Even the grandson of the founder of the Islamic revolution, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, may not pass the tough vetting procedure. Hassan Khomeini — who is allied with reformists and whose candidacy has outraged hardliners — is obliged to take a test on Tuesday to certify he is a suitably senior cleric to enter into the Experts Assembly, which could decide on who should be Iran’s next supreme leader.
Even so, reformist analysts say that while senior political leaders may approve a crackdown on reformists, they doubt they would have given the green light to storm an embassy. The international repercussions for such a drastic move would be too severe for the country.
Even a hardline cleric such as Ahmad Khatami, who leads Tehran’s Friday prayers, condemned the attack on the embassy.
Mr Khatami said that “we don’t achieve anything by attacking embassies and setting fire to them” and that “it was not appropriate to attack the Saudi embassy and consulate ”.
If the attack leads to the barring of Iranians travelling to the Hajj pilgrimage in Mecca, it would prove particularly embarrassing for the country’s senior leaders.
Iran’s supreme leader and ultimate decision maker, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, had warned after a similar attack on the British embassy in Tehran in 2011 that diplomatic missions should enjoy complete security.
Hardliners might be staunch supporters of Iran’s supreme leader, but analysts say that they cannot resist the opportunity to weaken their rivals.
Ayatollah Khamenei cannot afford to allow severe prosecution of those embassy demonstrators as they have come to the Islamic Republic’s aid before and carried out brutal crackdowns on opposition movements.
“Hardliners need to radicalise the political and social atmosphere so they can eliminate their rivals under the pretext of national security,” Mr Javadi-Hesar added.
“Their number in various centres may be equal to a few brigades who can be quickly organised to confront people with moderate groups who are now identified with Mr Rouhani.”
